reviewText: Pretty much anyone born in the 1980's will testify to being a Turtles fan. They were everywhere. More toys than any kid could ever dream of collecting, a long-running animated series, Halloween costumes, t-shirts, underwear, heck, they even made their own album and performed in concert! It only made sense that they would hit the big screen not, once, not twice, but thrice during their reign of popularity in the late 80's/early 90's. I was lucky enough to see the first two flicks in theaters, and basked in the glory of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles for every second they were on the screen. Granted, by the time the third movie arrived, I considered myself too old for these movies and snubbed it. Yet, many years later, as an adult, I still find these movies (for the most part) to be entertaining, not just as a nostalgic trip back to simpler times, but because they were always flat-out, fun movies that people of all ages could find something to appreciate. Even as a new generation of Turtle fans are arriving, with a new movie in tow, the original movies still stand strong.Just like any successful film franchise, the first movie is always the best, with each sequel degrading the legacy further and further. In 1990, we got to see our heroes in a half-shell like never before. "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" brought the four turtles and their master, Splinter, to life thanks to full body suits and animatronics. Even today, I have to say, without bias, that the costumes still look convincing. The only flaw I have found is that the Turtles' lips didn't always move properly, but such a thing can be forgiven. The first movie does an excellent job of setting up the origins of the Turtles, while keeping the tone more serious than that of the TV show. Not to say that there isn't humor in this movie, because there is. The original "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles" does a splendid job of walking the line between the dark comic books and the colorful TV show. Kids can enjoy it, and parents can appreciate it's story and overall message of brotherhood. Even I'll admit to getting choked up every now and again on Splinter's talk with Raphael early in the movie. I can honestly say I appreciate this movie on the same level as some of my other favorites, even if it is considered a kid's movie.The second movie, "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: Secret Of The Ooze," came along just a year later, and boy, you can tell they rushed things. Granted, the costumes are improved and there is decidely more action than the first, but the story is as flat as a slice of pepperoni. Aside from the Turtles looking to the origins of the ooze that mutated them, there really isn't anything going on storywise. As a kid, I enjoyed this movie more than the first, simply because it delivers the instant gratification of Turtle-action that we all craved at the time. Looking back now, it is definitely inferior to the first, but still enjoyable. And it's priceless to see Vanilla Ice up on-stage, doing the infamous "Ninja Rap."Now, with the third movie, they took their time. Two years, as a matter of fact. Unfortunately, though, you wouldn't be able to tell. This movie is just about unwatchable. Only a die-hard fan or a small child could appreciate it, and even that's a stretch. The story involes the Turtles travelling back to ancient Japan where they fight against some horribly cliched and bland characters. What was the point in placing the Turtles in ancient Japan? So we could discover the origins of the Foot Clan, perhaps? Nope. There is simply nothing in this movie that relates to the rest of the "TMNT" universe. The costumes are terrible, the voices are worse, and what on Earth did they do to Splinter? Our wise leader has been reduced to a muppet. Watching this movie, it's easy to see why they held off for fourteen years on making a new movie. "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III," unfortunately, ends the trilogy on a sour note.Despite the third movie being a stinker, these are still really fun movies. Whether you're looking for a slice of childhood to latch onto, or if you want to introduce your children to some classics, this is a good place to start. Unfortunately, there are no special features to speak of, which is surprising, especially with their success. At the very least, the first movie should have gotten better treatment than this. If you were ever a Turtles fan, surely it's worth looking into these films again, and at the price, you can't complain.
summary: Two Out Of Three Ain't Bad.

reviewText: TMNT 1: Nice and dark, had a slight tang of the comic books while staying kid-friendly (for the most part).  Animatronics aren't so hot, but admit it -- you're not watching it for special effects anyway! The story is wonderfully goofy: basically setting up the TMNT vs. Shredder, but including such ridiculous themes as ninjas corrupting NYC's easily addled youth in a coordinated effort to steal wallets and random valuables (no doubt to add to Shredder's impressive wall of televisions).  But don't let that turn you off... it's a fun flick because it's so delightfully campy, and you can't go wrong with it.TMNT II: TMNT II is not as dark and contains about 90% more cheese than #1.  This said, I enjoy TMNT 2 just as much as I enjoy TMNT 1, just for different reasons.  Perhaps because it reminds me so strongly of the Saturday Morning cartoon -- it has such a good heart and is so ridiculous that you can't help but come away from it feeling pleasant.  Better yet, I feel they tried to include all of the Turtles instead of focusing so much on Raphael.  The humor hits the mark almost every time: who can forget lines like "Too Raph!", and how can one not erupt into laughter when a stunned Shredder is warmly embraced by his idiotic mutant cronies?  The animatronics/suits look great -- they're easily the best looking in the trilogy.  Can't go wrong with the simple story, either -- it hits the right key with some mutant mayhem in the forms of Tokka and Rahzar, mutants who Shredder creates to defeat the Turtles.  The most important and enjoyable part: "Ninja Rap."  Need I say more?TMNT 3: I never watched this as a child.  So when I got the 3-Pak in, I decided to try it out.  Unfortunately, it's terrible enough to burn your eyes out: the animatronics/suits are downright awful (the Turtle suits look like they came out of one of those egg machines in the supermarket), the dialogue is goofy, the plot is cheap and idiotic - well, I guess if I were more subjective, I could say that about the other two movies, but at least those campy plots fit with who the TMNT were. This one departs from the TMNT with gusto: they are transported to feudal Japan (utterly out of their element -- part of what makes them interesting is the idea that they could be lurking unseen beneath your feet in a sewer somewhere), where they are accepted by a whole Japanese village with open arms (despite that much of their allure is that they are pariahs), and some villains who are goofy rather than threatening (come on: Shredder could rip your face off... Tokka and Rahzar could throw a 200-pound Turtle thirty feet in the air... and then in TMNT 3 you have a shrimpy daimyo with the wide-eyed gaze and shakes of a chihuahua and some pasty-faced gunrunner with finches).  I would have felt cheated had I not realized that you're essentially paying only for TMNT 1&2. 3 was thrown in as a gag, I suppose.Overall: 3 aside, this is a collection you can't do without.  The nostalgic value alone is monumental.  And the movies are still enjoyable for kids of all ages - ideal for passing on a little of that TMNT bug to future generations! Definitely a must-buy for any TMNT fan, young or old.
Title: N/A

reviewText: lets face this topic first. The standards by which films are made in present day aren't as they once were back in the early 90's. I myself now have to laugh at some of the ridiculous stuff thats going on in the Ninja Turtles movies. No not the comedy, but say the second films lack of plot or the ever changing cast over the three films. HOWEVER! If you were a fan of these movies long ago when growing up, I beleive you will enjoy revisiting these films. The first film is great and today possibly could pass as a B film. The other two are great for fans, admitidly not as good as the first but at the same time, I feel today these flicks might have gone straight to video. Don't get me wrong. I love these movies. They are a part of my childhood and a part of me. Yet, I am saying the above to tell all film enthusiasts that these aren't "Great films" for film fans. They are for fans of the Turtles and as that, these films triumph. Recapture the magic of these films as they are now avalible in this DVD 3 set. and for the cost, I dobt see how anyone could possibly regret buying these sweet movies. Thanks for reading. hope it was helpful.
summary: recapturing the magic that was turtle!

reviewText: I may have an unfair rating on this set because I used to watch these movies ALL the time when I was younger; I was definitely obsessed. But aside from that I think that the movies are actually not that bad. The first movie is a good representation of the original storyline (with a few differences), and is overall a pretty good movie. The second movie was pretty good, not as good as the first but still decent. The third just seemed like they wanted to continue the series so they threw it together; not too bad but also not the best. I think that people who weren't into Ninja Turtles or into other 80s/90s cartoons (or comics) wouldn't really like these movies but if you're willing to buy them these movies are a great gift for kids.
summary: Brings back memories of the early 90s!

reviewText: made before cgi was the standard in film making. back when actors wore costumes rather than having it added later via computer. it has it's charm and may be a bit cheesy, but overall it's still fun. Oddly you find yourselves feeling for these Jim Henson created Turtles. You actually wish you knew these guys in real life as they are having fun doing what they love to do. It has that classic 80s/90s charm and brang to life the old saturday morning cartoons as well as some of the flavor of the comic. Fun to watch if you grew up with it or even if you just want to introduce the fun of the Turtles to a new generation. The transfer looks good and sounds good (though I am not sure what more they could do considering the age of the movies) the price is great, and you get them all in one case (each blu ray is designed to look like a pizza). You really can't ask for a better deal.

reviewText: it your a long time fan of the turtles like i am you should pick this up right away!!! im happy that this particular collection didnt come with the animated movie, which wasnt bad in itself, but still prefered the movies. part 1 was always my fav of the three because it had that more dark tone where the turtle wasnt too campy as the other too. plus it felt more gritty as well. but i have to say iv'e been waiting for years for this 3 pack to arrive and its finally here for all the true fans out there. it was great seeing these movies again after soo many years. this is something that you can pass on to your kids to see. great for the next generation of fans to come.

reviewText: Turtles 1 :  t.v. news reporter April O'Neil, & Casey Jones join forces with the Turtles in a fight against a secret organization known only as The Foot Clan. which threaten the city, especially its youth by recruiting them. behind it all is an unknown enemy who after kidnapping Master Splinter (the turtles sensei) is seeking to destroy the Turtles...The Shredder. as to the Blu-ray itself i really loved the film transfer, many people on here have stated that it's "too grainy" but while yes there is a slight graininess it is not even close to as bad as the DVD counterpart i've owned for years. very nicely done HD transfer!! audio is English Dolby TrueHD 5.1 & English Dolby Digital 5.1Turtles 2: taking place supposedly the night after the events in the first film this movie delves into the Turtles & Master Splinter's past, which comes back to haunt them in the forms of Tokka, Rahzar, The Shredder & the ooze which transformed the turtles 15 years ago. and to add to the Turtles headache they must also try and find a new home in this decently made sequel. as for the Blu-ray, again very nicely done HD transfer!! the film is dedicated to the memory of Jim Henson RIP.turtles 3: The gang is back & greener than ever in this third installment. a golden scepter  bought by the Turtles friend and news reporter April O'Neil turns out to be an ancient relic which when activated is a time device that trades places with the holder from the past and from our present. in this case happens to be April who trades places with a ancient Japanese Warrior. enlisting the help of their pal Casey Jones to watch their master Splinter the four brothers go back to try and save April and along the way meet someone that could very well be a distant relative of Casey Jones. they also learn of a prophecy which foretold of their coming to help stop a new enemy...as for the blu-ray very awesome job on the HD transfer again.all 3 discs have no special features and autoplay when you watch them.*NOTE: if you'd like to enjoy the Dolby TrueHD audio you'll have to change the audio settings in the pop-up menu screen
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just recently bought this box set to relive my childhood. I grew up on the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. I watched the cartoon, collected the trading cards, etc. However, I knew that there would be no way I'd enjoy these as much as I did when I was a kid.Although, I do have to say that the first movie holds up quite well. I still laughed as most of the parts I was supposed to laugh at, and the movie still felt dark. The second one not as much, but it is still fun. It suffers from that "dated" feel it has, particularly with the Vanilla Ice music scene that goes on for waaaaaay too long, and the poor "Tokka" and "Rahzar" costumes. And why does "Mutant Shredder" have clothes that fit him and spikes on his clothing that grew in size? The third one is slightly better than I remember, since I am less frustrated now than I was back then that no villains from the cartoon were in the movie. However, the movie still is not that great and is the most cheesy of them all. And Casey Jones' character was way underused.In the end these are great for kids, but the adults will really only dig the first one - and only if they liked these when they were young.
Title: N/A

reviewText: These films are such amazing classics from my generation I was so excited to see the trilogy coming to blu-ray...however, my hopes were pretty much shattered.  I received it today and have watch the first two films.I was hoping for a high quality transfer - but they look no better than vhs/dvd...the picture is grainy and definitely not the high quality one expects from a blu-ray...even if it is 1080 dpi, it doesn't do much if the transfer is poor quality!There are really no extras which I was hoping for - especially since the turtles are the work of jim henson's studio, and I still think they are impressive even today.  I was hoping for some behind the scenes and current interviews...outside of trailers, there is no real extras.Also, the sound quality is terrible!! I get an echoey sound on my surround sound, even when other blu-rays play fine!Is it worth the price???given the price is pretty cheap, it is a great deal for a 3 blu-ray set.  If you already own the dvds, then don't bother.I have the first two on dvd and didn't want to spend a lot on the third (since it isn't that great), so this is a nice way of owning the whole set.  All up to you!  All I can say, this set is a disappointment to cult classic fans who are hoping for an improved transfer and some awesome extras!

reviewText: I'm going to assume that most people looking at this product know the movies and are probably looking to update their VHS or DVD versions of these movies.  With that, I must say that I was somewhat disappointed with the sound and appearance of these movies.  Since the introduction of Blu Ray, many studios have gone to great lengths to get the best sound and picture quality on Blu Ray.  Some prime examples are Caddyshack, Batman (1989), or Wizard of Oz.  Many times, you can notice an instant improvement, without needing a side by side comparison.  With these movies, I popped in my old DVD's to see if I could notice a difference.  While there was an improvement, I must say that it was minimal.  I seriously think that someone was sitting at a computer, hit "convert" and made the Blu Ray versions now for sale.Don't get me wrong, true Turtles fans will want to pick up this set, and the picture quality is slightly better, but don't expect to be blown away by crystal clear anything.Please note: when you look at other reviews, you'll notice that most of them are recycled from the DVD boxed set.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 3-Pak!  That includes, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles part II - The Secret of the Ooze, and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles part III. About three turtles who made thier wat into a puddle of radioactive waste, that turned these turtles into radical reptiles, that are transformed into New York City's greatest crime-fighting quartet.Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (1990)- Directed by Steve Barron. Starring the cast of Judith Hoag, Elias Koteas, and Corey Feldman. The Movie is the live-action, feature film adaptation of the cult comic book and the popular animated television show. After prolonged exposure to radiation, four teenage turtles--Michelangelo, Raphael, Leonardo, and Donatello--have mutated into ninjas and have begun living in the sewers of a large city. Under the guidance of a ninja master Splinter the Rat and television reporter April, the Turtles embark on a mission to run crime out of the city and battle the warlord Shredder.Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II - The Secret of the Ooze (1991)- Directed by Michael Pressman. Starring the cast of Joseph Amodei and Kurt Bryant.The evil Shredder believes he's found what gives the turtles their power and proceeds to create dangerous mutants. Armed with Professor Perry's anti-mutant antidote, it's up to the crime fighting turtles and a pizza delivery boy to conquer these mutants.Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III (1993)- Directed by Stuart Gillard. Starring the cast of Elias Koteas and Paige Turco. Everybody's favorite giant turtles travel through time and space to feudal Japan to rescue their plucky sidekick April, when a golden sword accidentally causes her to switch places with a rebellious samurai.DVD Special Features for the movies include:Interactive Menus, Theatrical Trailers, stills and more.

reviewText: Everyone should agree that the 1st film is the best, with its dark tone but still very funny and  quirky. the 2 and 3 are just plain kids stuff. it's kinda hard to watch them again, especially when you're 26. fortunately nostalgia compensates all that. one big letdown of course is the extras..not much going on there. i could only imagine how good the set would be if they had more stuff. i don't know, commentaries like the TMNT dvd which was very fun to listen to, behind the scenes etc etc.but all we have are a bunch of old trailers and lame features. the 4 stars are solely based on the great shape the films are. if you miss these films, then i suggest you buy this collection while it's pretty cheap. cowabunga.....

reviewText: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Trilogy is a three-DVD box set that features the famous comic-book martial-arts pizza-loving reptile heroes.Part One-The Original Movie: The Turtles makes their live-action film debut as meet April O'Neil, confront the sports vigilante Casey Jones and square off against the Shredder and his Foot clan.Part Two-The Secret of the Ooze: The Turtles faces a new threat as Shredder unleashes new evil mutant monsters. With the help of Keno, a pizza delivery boy(portrayed by real-life martial arts expert Ernie Reyes Jr.), the TNMT are ready to battle. Look for a cameo appearance by then-rap music megastar Vanilla Ice. LOLPart Three-Turtles In Time: The Turtles are back in their final chapter as they go back in time to 1603 Japan to save April from an power-mad samurai warlord.The Ninja Turtles Trilogy are perfect for any TMNT fan and will introduces fans of the 2003 Ninja Turtles cartoon to this classic family film series.
summary: My Review Of The Ninja Turtles Trilogy

reviewText: Now I love the Teeage Mutant Ninja Turtles live action movies. The first one is classic, the 2nd one has it's flaws but it's a ton of fun and my personal favorite, the 3rd one whitch alot of people hate, I personely enjoyed it. I own each movie on vhs and I never really got around to geting the DVDs but when I found this blu ray at wal mart for 15$ I had to get it. The blu ray has the 3 movies on seprate discs that have pizza designs on them, The quality is mostly good but not to impressive. The first film compared to the vhs looks great, the colors are more brighter and details are easier to see, It still has a fuzzy look to it but over all it looks good. also the sound is more clear. But even with all that, this blu ray dosen't have any worth while extras, it only has a trailer for the movie and a sneak peek video for the video game TMNT Smash Up. The second film compared to the first film's quality, it's not as impressive, the colors still look brighter and the detail once again are easier to see. But the film still has that fuzzy look to it, I often thought that it was the DVD of the movie with hardley any major clean ups. and like the first movie, hardley any worth while extras, just the trailer for the movie. So over all the quality is alright. Now the 3rd movie, now I know that the people that hate the 3rd film aren't gonna be happy about this but the 3rd film's quality looks great, the colors are vibrant, the details are superb. but just like the 1st and 2nd, no worth while extras, just a trailer for the movie. But overall, this blu ray set is very worth while for turtle fans, despite some flaws in the quality, it's the best these movies have ever look, and those who coulden't affored the collecter's edtion on blu ray, then this set is well worth the money.

reviewText: This three pack of the movies of the heroes in a half shell are not for all, but seeing as how the kids are starting to get into the new version of the TMNT you parents wont be completly bored watching this action packed movie of 4 walking talking mutated ninja turtles!The first movie is defenitly the best!The city of New York is under a crime wave that the police have no leads on, and things are beeing stolen from under people noses in the blink of an eye! Its beeing run by an anceint group of ninja thieves known as "the foot". And is lead by "Tatsu" a rough asian mucho man with great knowledge of martial arts, and also trains the youths who join this footclan, and he is second in command to the boss "Shredder", one of the coolest looking bad guys in history! So with the police not able to find out what is going on? A news reporter accidently gets involved in her story trying to promote this underground crime wave that the police are trying to pretend isnt happening, and she gets a little too involved, and when the foot are sent to silence her, she accidently finds her self involved with four walking talking ninja turtles "Leonardo" "Donatello" "Raphial" and "Michaelangeo" and of coarse there father type figure and mentour "Master Splinter"! The film has its storys along the way and is filled with martial arts, comedy and fun, and some great work on the costumes of the turtles by Jim Henson that wont leave you thinking "they look fake!" you may just beleive these guys are real! This movie inspired from the cartoon is a great flick for the action fans of a diffrent kind!Its first seaqull "Secret of the ooze" isnt as great as the first! It takes place shortly after the events of the first movie and does not conatain much of the original cast. It did have a few moments of comic releif, but the new addition of a charactoer named "keno" who is a martial arts studying Pizza boy wasnt exactly needed for this film, but it wasnt all that bad!And the third movie April has found an old antique as a present for Splinter, however unaware, its a time traveling device! And she is sent back in time to ancint Japan! And the Turtles have to go back and get her! The 3rd is much better then part 2, but still not as good as part 1! But the three movies are great and worth buying together! There not overlly violent or set bad egsamples for kids, there ninja comedys and as long as you can stand them, these movies are great!It's a shame none of them come with any bonus features like deleted scenes or featurettes. Maybe one day New Line will release special editions, but till then, this is the best you can get.

reviewText: The story and mood declined with each successive film which is a shame.The first film is cheesy but it had a really distinct look to it, it was dark and the mood was semi-serious for a comic/cartoon based film adaptation. I think they nailed something there.The second film really tried to be more like the cartoon with the introduction of the 2 new mutants straight out of Power Rangers/Godzilla aesthetic. These could be done with CGI today but back then it was men in rubber suits.The third film has a shabbiness to it and a very disjointed feel to it. Taking the storyline in the past to feudal Japan was silly. Everything else felt like two movie types were mashed together.

reviewText: Not to be confused for a collection digitally remastered for sound and picture quality, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 3-Pak simply bundles the previously releasedTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtles(1990),Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II: The Secret of the Ooze(1991) andTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III(1993) into one handy, reasonably priced boxed set. I knew this going into the purchase, and so should you. With the exception of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (the best of the three films) which unfortunately features the same grainy-at-times video quality of the VHS edition (if not more), the films look pretty good and sound nice in 5.1 Dolby Surround. Features include Widescreen and Fullscreen versions of the films; Closed Captioning; English subtitles; Animated Menus; Interactive games; Character biographies; and Trailers. I picked up this collection on the cheap following the big screen release of the CGI-animated feature filmTMNT(2007). Until someone gets wise and release a remastered collection, this Turtles 3-Pak is a good, cheap way to preserve the live action Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Trilogy on DVD.
summary: Heroes On The Half Shell On The Cheap

reviewText: Although the story and the characters are OK the special effects seem dated and laughable - I seem to remember they were state-of-the-art for their time.  The good news is it's all "cartoony" and fairly corny so little kids won't care anyway. I bought this for my 4 year old daughter and we had a pretty good time laughing and goofing around with our pretend martial arts.  It's amazing what kids can imitate with only a single viewing.
summary: 80s SFX Seem A Hundred Years Old

reviewText: To quote from an article, "One night in 1984, Comic Artist Kevin Eastman came home from a party one night with his fellow artist and friend Peter Laird and felt like drawing some random pictures of something that would capture his mood of feeling silly." Kevin got the crazy notion (probably from having too many drinks) to draw a big turtle wearing a mask and holding a pair of nuchukus. Peter drew some pictures along with Kevin just for the sake of entertaining a silly notion. Little did they know that a simple drawing would soon become a million dollar franchise. Ninja Turtle Mania swept America from 1987 to 1993. From cloths, food, toys, a television series, and video games to live action movies, Ninja Turtles marked one of America's cultural icons. Now onto the Ninja Turtle movie trilogy... The first film in 1989 not only captured the live action accuracy of the comic based turtles, it also did a good job of explaining the long rival between Splinter and Shredder as well as how the turles came to be along with managing to draw casual movie viewers to becoming fans of the Ninja Turtles story. The script was well written in terms of character and plot development. Not only that, the acting was very believable for costumed turtles and the villains weren't cartoony so to say. The dvd version is in widescreen and offers some bonus features though not anything extraordinary. On a sad note, the picture and sound quality are not up to par for dvd standards but this does not take away in my opinion from the enjoyment of watching the movie. In 1991, the sequel 'Secret of the Ooze' hit theaters following right where the first movie left off. Though I can see why it received mixed reviews, I enjoyed it as much as the first. Granted, the producers took a risk aiming the sequel solely at ninja turtle fans versus the casual movie viewer. The violence was toned down a bit, the comedy level was turned up a notch, and Casey Jones did not return. Despite all that, the film did a good job revisiting the origin of the ooze as well as how the turtles came to be. There were also other mutants added to the film, the actress who replaced April from the first movie did just as good of a job, and though the concept of Shredder drinking the ooze at the end was somewhat corny, it still faired well. Who can also forget the uncalled for yet entertaining scene with Vanilla Ice's "Ninja Rap" near the end of the movie? The dvd version is in widescreen and offers a good bonus feature different from the first movie though that is about it. At least the picture and sound quality for the Secret of the Ooze dvd is clear and crisp. The second ninja turtles movie did well enough at the box office to spawn yet another sequel 'Turles In Time'. By this point in late 1993, the ninja turtle fad had begun to die down and not as many people were flocking to the theater to see what would be the last installment of the ninja turtle films. Turtles in Time was quite different from the standard plot of the ninja turtle adventures doing away with Shredder, the foot clan, and present New York City for that matter. The third ninja turtle flick unfortunately did not do well at the box office. I personally feel that it was highly underrated. Sure, the costumes were different, some of the actors were different, the concept of going back to 17th century Japan was far fetched, and I will agree that Turtles In Time should not have been an end to the series. Still, Casey Jones returned even if his role was not as involved as say April's, there were plenty of action sequences along with fight scenes, and I think what made the movie shine was showing the educational history of ancient Japan which included trading with the Europeans as well as the culture wars while mixing the ninja turtle adventure along with it. Because of these good aspects, I enjoyed this third installment as much as the previous two. The dvd version like the previous is in widescreen and has good picture/sound quality. The bonus features on the downside are the exact same as the previous sequel. Nothing new was added. My overall opinion of the trilogy is that each film managed to entertain the ninja turtle fan such as myself. If you are grown and had never been into ninja turtles, you may not enjoy these movies. Otherwise, you turtle fans out there should agree that the movies might not have been so good had they been based on the original cartoon series versus the comics. As for my review on the dvds themselves, more bonus features should have been added. There was a separate vhs release called Behind the Shells that showed the making of the first two ninja turtle movies. In the video, cast members were interviewed, puppeteering effects in addition with coordinated fight sequences were shown along with outtakes, an interview with the director, conversations with Keven Eastman and Peter Laird on creating the ninja turtles comic series along with how they came up with the character of Oroku Saki a.k.a Shredder (can you tell I've been a turtle fan for sometime?). This documentary should have been added as a bonus disk to the boxset along with deleted scenes, music videos, and bonus episodes from the new ninja turtles series. Maybe a director's cut of all three movies could have been done as well. I also want to mention that all three movies had excellent soundtracks that I still listen to from time to time. Oh well, one can only hope that a special edition re-release is in the near future following the next ninja turtles movie should it ever get made.
summary: for the kid ninja in most of us (or some of us)
Title: N/A
